description: From Middle English bekenen, beknen, becnen, beknien, from Old English bēacnian, bēcnian, bīecnan (“to signal; beckon”), from Proto-West Germanic *bauknōn, *bauknijan (“to signal”), from *baukn (“signal; beacon”). Cognate with Old Saxon bōknian, Old High German bouhnen, Old Norse bákna. More at beacon.

entries.meaning: A sign made without words; a beck.
A children's game similar to hide and seek in which children who have been "caught" may escape if they see another hider beckon to them.

verbs.description: beckon (third-person singular simple present beckons, present participle beckoning, simple past and past participle beckoned)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To wave or nod to somebody with the intention to make the person come closer.
examples: His distant friends, he beckons near.

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To seem attractive and inviting
